Truck asked me to record my experiences at my new job.
I feel I have to explain a little first. I'm 32. I have two girls whom I love and I want to do everything in the world for them. Right now I stay home with them during the week while my wife (whom I will refer to as E) works. Two days a week they go to daycare. Now, the particular day care they go to is one of the best in Minneapolis in my humble opinion. They love the staff and the other kids and so we want to keep them there. We are, however, slowly going in to debt. So, at E's prompting I began looking for part-time work. "No problem," I thought. "I have skills." I thought I could easily find work that would, at least in some way, utilize my skills. Boy was I wrong. Maybe it's September 11, or whatever, but I ended up working in a chain coffee joint. (Not Starbucks.) Today was my third day.
Well, the pay is a little dismal. I'm expected to accept this meager pay, and somehow make this part-time job part of my identity. Now I like coffee. I probably like it more than most. I don't, however, want to make it a major part of my life. I think this is the most insidious part of the work culture in the U.S. We're supposed to take these shit jobs and then act like we're the luckiest damn people in the world to be working there. I had to go through two interviews to get this job. I couldn't help thinking, "I'm an adult. I'll show up. I'll do the work. What more do you want for this kind of pay?" Two damn interviews. It felt like a colossal waste of time. Of course I disguised my cynicism so successfully that they actually hired me.
So here I am, learning this new job. One of my supervisors wasn't even born yet when I got my driver's license. All my coworkers are twenty-somethings, although they all seem nice. I'm just not in the same place they are. Let me tell you, it put me into a depression for several days when I first got the job. I kept asking myself how I got to a place where I could do no better than slinging coffee for shit pay.
Well, it hasn't been as bad as I thought. As E will often point out, I often focus on the negatives. I still don't relish the job and I'm embarassed to tell my friends and family that I work there. Trucker says I shouldn't be embarassed. He has some valid points.
I just had this illusion that I was Randy from Cryptonomicon . I was ready for a substantive change in my outlook. I was ready to do what I needed to do for my family. Unfortunately I thought it would be something cooler, or more in line with my interests than a job that any 16 year-old could get.
I guess things don't happen quite like that in life. It works well for fiction, but those kind of changes don't occur overnight. It's usually years later that, in retrospect, we can point to a time or an event that changed our lives or our outlook. In the end I guess I did what was right for my family. (With tips, I make around $10/hr., which isn't bad for part-time work, and that kind of pay was my central-albeit modest-goal to begin with.) So today I'm feeling better about things.
E is going to kill me if I don't get some more things done around the house before she gets home. I don't know how often I can update this stupid thing. Hopefully I can do it often enough, I don't want to abandon it, but I really don't have time for another hobby. Wish me luck.

[Wringing my hands.] Okay, here goes. Let me explain a couple of things first. I think Neal Stephenson put it best in Zodiac when the main character (whose name I can't remember now) says, "I am, as everyone knows, an asshole." You might as well add cynic to that list. My politics are sometimes radical, my outlook is often glib. I'm self-effacing a lot of the time, I'm also not afraid to criticize others, at least in my thoughts. I'm not always nice.
With that being said, don't expect you to always like or agree with what I say. I certainly don't expect you to do so. I don't want to argue with anyone, I just want to say what I want to say at the time I'm saying it. I might retract it later. I might not. Don't e-mail me please. If you don't like what I'm saying, don't read this anymore. I'm hoping this format will be some kind of format/space for me to express thoughts I don't always get to express. It may be at times mundane. Hopefully once in a great while it will be thought-provoking, or even humorous.

Okay, anyone who knows anything about programming is going to laugh. Especially if you read further and find all my references to Neal Stephenson. But I just spent about 9-10 hours writing programs for my Visual Basic class I took this Spring. One was an assignent that was due a couple of weeks ago. The other was my final project. Anyone who actually does programming for a living knows how trivial this is. It's not the cool Perl included in the text of Cryptonomicon . But it took me all damn day. Now I've got my sister's iBook up on the couch, networked with my other computer downstairs so I still have internet access, and my G4 down in the basement acts as an mp3 server as well. (I should take a second that as I've been writing, Jay Farrar, segued into Buck Owens, into Pete Yorn.) So, E was kind enough to watch the girls all day so I could get greasy in front of the computer. Believe me, it was a beautiful Sunday and I could think of better things to do. (That's not to say that I haven't spent many a day in front of the computer, ignoring the weather.)
So without further ranting, here is the fruit of my labor:
Dim item() Dim price() As Single Dim a As String, b As Single, c As Single, d As String, e As Single, total As Single, i As String, j As Single, quantity As Single
Private Sub cmdAdd_Click() i = lstGroceries.ListIndex + 1 j = price(lstGroceries.ListIndex + 1) quantity = Val(txtQuantity) If quantity = 0 Then quantity = 1 End If total = total + (j * quantity) lblTotal.Caption = "Total bill is " & FormatCurrency(total) picDisplay.Print lstGroceries.List(i), FormatCurrency(j), FormatCurrency(j * quantity) End Sub
Private Sub cmdClear_Click(Index As Integer) picDisplay.Cls 'clears the picture box lblTotal.Caption = "" total = 0 End Sub
Private Sub Form_Load() Dim x As Integer Open "C:\WINDOWS\Desktop\visual basic\final project\food.txt" For Input As #1 Do While Not EOF(1) Input #1, a, x b = b + 1 Loop Close #1 Open "C:\WINDOWS\Desktop\visual basic\final project\food.txt" For Input As #1 ReDim item(1 To b) ReDim price(1 To b) Do While Not EOF(1) c = c + 1 Input #1, d, e item(c) = d price(c) = e Loop Close #1 Call sortData Call loadList End Sub
Private Sub sortData() Dim passNum As Single, k As Single, temp As String, temp2 As Single For passNum = 1 To (b - 1) For k = 1 To b - passNum If item(k) > item(k + 1) Then temp = item(k) temp2 = price(k) item(k) = item(k + 1) price(k) = price(k + 1) item(k + 1) = temp price(k + 1) = temp2 End If Next k Next passNum End Sub
Private Sub loadList() Dim f As Integer For f = 1 To b lstGroceries.AddItem item(f) Next f End Sub
If you haven't guessed [Dylan is now playing] it's a program that loads a list of grocery items from a data file, then allows you to select what you want, then it gives you a total. Pretty boring.
My good friend Eric, whom I'll see in AZ next week, once said something about things like this that always stuck with me. "You know, you spend all these years learning to be an engineer and you expect to be designing bridges and cool stuff. Then you spend the next ten years designing bolts." It's not an exact quote and he's not an engineer, but you get the idea. I probably won't ever write cool decryption programs. Maybe, just maybe I'll get to do more than grocery programs.

There is a real problem with our culture as a whole. Mediocrity. My original impetus for this blog was our urlLink president . President Bush, I suppose, is a kind of poster boy for mediocrity. He's living proof that the cream really doesn't rise to the top in the U.S. Here our C students from rich families, with failed businesses can rise to the highest office in the land. It's the Larry Flynts, not the Martin Luther Kings, who fight to preserve our constitutional rights. No more do we demand the best. I suppose Bush is a kind of McPresident. The ultimate franchise. We knew exactly what we were getting. Like walking into any McDonalds, or going to see the latest Star Wars movie, he's familiar and seemingly innocuous. We're willing to settle for that. I'm speaking of the United States in a collective sense, of course. (Before I get spammed with hate-mail from rabid, greasy Star Wars fanatics, I LOVE Star Wars. Stick with me here, I'm trying to make a point.)
But really the problem is much larger than President Bush. There are exceptions, but for the most part, we produce the biggest, ugliest most inefficient cars. We produce the urlLink worst PC software , or at least the worst PC software is the most popular here. We've got the worst education system of any industrialized country. We've also got the highest infant mortality rate of any industrialized country. I could go on, but you get the point.
How is it that the largest economy in the world is dead-set in the middle? How do former pro wrestlers become state governors? Why is blandness so widespread in what is touted as "The Greatest Nation on Earth?"
I find it particularly hard to identify with this America while we're at war. When a sort of sloganeering, oversimplified kind of patriotism is everywere. I have to remind myself of the real valuable part of American culture. The parts I do identify with very strongly. I'm, of course, talking about jazz, the blues, rock and country music. I'm talking about my right to lambast the president when I think he deserves it. (I think he deserves it a lot.) I'm talking about a rich history of dissidence.
So why does the popular culture of the U.S. seem so mired in the creamy middle? Maybe the "Greatest Nation on Earth" myth has always been just that. A myth I've deconstructed in my adult life. Maybe it's because all the good parts of the culture are so good. In my opinion, the best stuff is closer to the fringes. To have such dizzying highs, one needs catrostrophic lows I suppose. The allowance for seemingly threatening behavior, creates more ideas out along the edges. To have such a large fringe, there must, almost by definition be a huge middle. Call it a bell curve philosophy of culture.
I'm particularly interested in this question, since I'm trying to raise two girls. I find the notion of ensuring that they develop into critical thinkers, a perplexing one. I don't want to seem like a total Neal Stephenson freak, but that's the thing I found particularly fascinating about The Diamond Age . How can I give my kids a set of ethics, a code to fall back on so they can navigate through life in a culture that rewards the insipid? How can I make sure they lead interesting lives? I'm only somewhat comforted by the fact that this same culture, these same institutions and systems, produced...me. I guess they have a fighting chance.

I was driving to pick E up from work this afternoon when some guy in an Intrepid pulled up behind me and proceeded to tailgate me for several blocks. It was at this point that I decided to employ what I like to call passive-agressive driving. My buddy Mav likes to do this. He does a lot of driving for his work and it seems to come up most on 394 for him.
You may not be reading this in Minneapolis, so I'll do a little explaining. I'm sure other metro areas around the country have them, but we have the sane-lane here that they open up for car-poolers during rush hour. (This is our convoluted way of dealing with mass-transit needs in our fair city.) Well, inevitably at some point the sane-lane dissappears and the people in that lane have to merge over with everyone else. Well, of course, instead of merging sanely, maybe a 1/2 mile or 1/4 mile ahead of time, they all speed up to the spot where they are absolutely forced to merge with traffic. They sort of force their way in. I'm sure most of you have experienced this. It's quite annoying. Well, in these instances, Mav pulls his car halfway into the lane so they're forced to slow down right away and merge instead of skipping to the front of the line. Quite often other cars ahead of him or behind him will do the same-all the while waving and yahooing to each other.
Well, in my case I was on 79th street in Bloomington (a Minneapolis suburb) when this Intrepid pulled up on my ass. It even had one of those stupid bras on. I could see the dude's perfectly quaffed hair and reflective sunglasses in my rear view mirror. Well, I proceeded to, rather innocently, slow down to 20 mph. This annoyed the guy to no end, I could tell. I could see him shake his head. He tried to pass me on the right, but had to pull back into my lane to avoid the parked cars. Of course, the light ahead was red, so I relished taking my time. I took great satisfaction in making this guy wait just a little longer. The best thing was that his car was so damn big that he couldn't pull around me to make his right turn once we got to the light. He had to wait, just like the rest of us.

I have this habit of seeing movies over several weeks. What happens is I'll be flipping through the channels and come across something I like, only I'll be 1/3 of the way into the movie. Then another day it will be rerun and I'll watch the part I missed before.
The latest movie I've watched this way is urlLink Contact . Now, I read the book when I was 15 and I saw the movie when it came out about 12 years later. I knew there would be differences between the movie and the book. I thought I knew what they were, but I couldn't fully trust my memory, so I decided to reread the book. Especially since there are interesting philosophical questions raised in the book that were not in the movie.
The thing I liked about the book then, and still like now, is the dialogue between the main character, Ellie and a televangelist named Palmer Joss. urlLink Carl Sagan actually treats Joss quite sympathetically. His character is intelligent and thoughtful. He and the Ellie do quite a bit of verbal sparring in the book.
In part of the book that I've recently reread, I came across an idea that I didn't catch when I was 15 and I find very interesting now. Ellie has just done some research to prepare for her first meeting with Joss. She comes across an early 20th century theologist named urlLink Rudolf Otto . Otto describes the mystic feeling one gets when contemplating divinity as urlLink "numinous." It's a sort of feeling of awe.
Now, Ellie asserts that scientists experience this same thing. They too contemplate the universe and experience the same sense of awe. She posits that religions try to institutionalize the numinous instead of providing a means to experience it directly. Scientists, she argues, have a kind of spiritual experience, but based on science and not religion or faith.
I think by the time I read this book I already had doubts about Catholicism. Looking back, this book was probably a factor in my rejecting rejecting it in my adult life. It certainly raises some good questions.

I just spent a four day weekend on a male bonding canoe trip. I barely knew the guys I went with. Now, generally speaking, I'm a pretty timid guy. I don't deal well with situations where I'm with a lot of people I don't know. In fact, I don't really like being in situations like that. I know it's probably not very healthy, but I've been this way my whole life. It's part of who I am and I'm not concerned with changing that part of my personality.
So there I was. The one guy I did know, who invited me, was in another vehicle picking people up in Belle Plaine, Kenyon and points beyond. I was in the metro contingent. I was in a urlLink Ford Excursion , a vehicle I despise, with three other guys whom I'd never met. It was 7 am and I hadn't slept well the night before.
At first I thought to myself, "This is going to suck. Who the hell are these guys? What am I doing?" They had all been on similar trips together years before. I was an inexperienced camper at best. I have to admit that in the back of my head I was following Shua's "Everything sucks until it's great" philosophy.
Well, I had one hell of a time with these guys. (There were a total of ten of us.) As corny as it sounds, I feel like we did actually bond on the trip. If you've ever canoed, you know the level of trust that you give to the person stearing the canoe when going through river rapids. Let me try to give a profile of the group as best I can. I got to know more about some than others. Here's what I could gather about the bunch of us.
First I suppose I should start with Jonathan. He's been the organizer of the trip every year for the last twelve years. He's the one I know and the one who, obviously, invited me. He bought most of the food, assigned us all with things to bring, including, but not limited to one bottle of booze a piece. A really good guy with a really bad back.
In Jonathan's canoe was Peter, the oldest on the trip. He'll turn 50 in July. Peter was the biggest pot smoker in the bunch. I'm not sure what he does for a living. He lives on a hobby farm in Kenyon, MN where he seems to live a sort of idyllic rural life. He likes to talk about his chickens. He makes a mean huevos rancheros on a camp fire. He reminds me of a slender Allen Ginsburg. I couldn't put my finger on this until he read some poetry. He wrote this short rap that he gave me permission to use if I wish:
I've got the white meat, I've got the white beat I've got a new car [waving finger] But I don't go far And I'm really thin 'Cause I'm taking Ritalin.
Keith was the guy who came to pick me up at 5:45 last Friday. The best way I could describe Keith is that he looks exactly like Dale on King of the Hill. He wears the hat, the reflective sunglasses and has the same scrawny build. He doesn't like to talk about black helicopters however. He's a mechanic who specializes in working on imports. With a little prompting I found out that he likes racing. He was the only one on the trip that talked less than I did. A nice guy really. He ended up stearing my canoe, even though he was used to being on the bow. We had a few dicey moments where I thought we were going to dump the canoe, but we never did.
Two guys were named Tom. Young Tom, as he was called, is a Northwest airlines pilot and incidentally flies planes exactly like urlLink this one . He was a goofy kind of guy and the weatherman on the trip. Being a pilot, he has an in-depth knowledge of weather patterns. He is also somewhat of a gadget collector. He has a four month old daughter with the same name as my wife.
In Young Tom's canoe was Kelly. I never could tell what Kelly did for a living. Apparently at different times he'd been a bartender, cook, and a freelance designer. He and his wife were about to move to Australia. He busied himself trying to fashion an anchor out of some stones and string, whittling drumsticks and trying to out-drink everyone else. He was the other newcomer on the trip.
The other Tom was a builder I think. I don't know much about him other than that he likes Led Zeppelin and Def Leppard. I think he likes most of the stuff they play on urlLink KQ . I think he has three kids. Nice guy, good fisherman.
In this Tom's canoe was Michael. Michael was a BIG guy. He's probably 6 ft. tall and at least 250 pounds. Most of it muscle. Just a bear. He's an insurance adjuster. He has very eclectic music tastes. He likes Jameson. Also an excellent fisherman. Even though I predicted that I'd want to avoid him, he was one of the nicest guys on the trip. He felt terrible that he kept me up all night the first night with his snoring.
In the last canoe was Phil. Phil is the owner of the Excursion. He owns the industrial sculpture company that does all the forests and animals for all the Rainforest Cafes. He has somewhere around 8 full-time employees. Really gregarious guy. Always helpful and friendly. I could forgive the obscene automobile since I'm sure his work requires some pretty heavy hauling. Plus, he's a super outdoors kind of guy. I bet his Excursion is one of the few out there that actually gets some off road use.
Phil was in the front of Tim's canoe. Tim was also known as a gadet guy. He was using a new kevlar canoe for the first time on this trip. He has an appreciation for Johnny Cash, even though he has some mistaken notions about Johnny's guitar playing. I think he was confusing Johnny's with Luther Perkins'. Funny guy. Likes cigars, good liquor and made up an improvised version of "I'll Fly Away" the first night that had us all rolling on the ground by the campfire.
I had one hell of a time with these good men. I'm already reserving the first weekend in June for next year.

If you're unfamiliar with the Turing Test, it's a test for urlLink artificial intelligence (AI) programs. Essentially, a person types questions into a computer terminal and there is a computer and one or two other people on computer terminals. The people and the computer program answer the questions. If the person can't tell which is the computer and which are the human subjects, the AI program is successful. It can "converse" as well as humans.
We've all spent time--probably a great deal of time--on some kind of customer service line waiting and then talking to someone to try to solve a problem. In almost every instance this is quite frustrating. Usually because you end up listening to cheesey music for 15 or more minutes before you get to talk to anyone. I'd say about 1/3 or 1/4 of the time it's frustrating because the person you talk to in incredibly unhelpful.
Now, I used to be patient with these people. I could sympathize because I knew they had a crappy job and didn't always have a lot of lattitude when it came to problem-solving. I was very patient, even apologetic, because I knew my problem was creating difficulty for them. Well, not any more. The problem, I think, is the whole damn culture. If they can't solve a simple problem, or even give a reasonable answer, then their whole damn workplace is disfunctional and by God, someone's going to here about it.
I submit that:
1.) There are no human beings in these alleged call centers. (Very unlikely.)
Or, as is more likely:
2.) The people answering the phones are so constrained, the workplace so dysfunctinal, their jobs so dismal, that once they enter the workplace, they are no longer human. At least not in an intellectual sense. They are reduced to automatons. Their minds shift into a kind of rudimentary AI state that is quickly confused by questions that cause them to deviate from a pat script. A script that probably sits on their desks in a three-ring binder. They answer a dozen or so questions a day for hundreds of people. When someone calls with a question that is outside of these 12; when they can't find it in their three-ring binders; they're like deer in car headlights. You the caller are the problem and they begin to treat you like you've come to beat them with baseball bats. You the caller become morally repugnant. (I should mention that I've worked on the phones at one such dysfunctional office. I hope I was more creative than some of the people I've recently dealt with. A few people would probably differ with me.)
Let me see if I can recreate a recent phone conversation I had with one such person. Now this involves UPS. I'd recieved something via UPS that was damaged. I'd finally arranged for reimbursement from the shipper if I could get something from UPS that said it was improperly packed.
ME: Hi, I recieved a package that was damaged. The shipper says he never recieved notification from you on the insurance claim. Could you just resend it to him?
UPS: I'm sorry sir, I can't release the information. It's UPS policy to only deal with the shipper.
ME: That's fine. I'm not asking you to send it to me. I want you to send it to him .
UPS: I'm sorry sir, the shipper will have to call and request that information. I show we sent him a letter on [such and such a date].
ME: Yeah, he claims he never recieved it. You see, if you send him another one, you would be dealing with the shipper. I don't need it. He does.
UPS: I'm sorry sir, I can only deal with the shipper. If he were to call we could send him a letter.
ME: [exasperated] Okay, fine. Can you do this for me? Can you send me a letter or even an e-mail saying it's your policy that you only deal with the shipper? I've gone through third-party mediation to get this guy to agree to pay. I just want something showing why I can't get this information for him.
UPS: I'm sorry sir, I don't have the ability to do that either.
ME: Why not?
UPS: I can't release that information sir. [You begin so see how the person is acting like a machine with their answers. The same answer to different questions. No ability to give a reasonable explanation.]
ME: [very exasperated] I'm not asking you release anything. You just said it's UPS policy. It's information you freely give out.
[I'm going to skip ahead now to the end after I've completely given up. Here's where I try once more to connect with them as another human being. One problem with this is that the person is really pissed-off at me.]
ME: So do you get a lot of complaints like this?
UPS: I don't understand the question sir.
ME: You know. You, as a person on the phones, do a lot of people call in with similar problems?
UPS: I assure you sir, we get many comments and we respond to all of them.
ME: [chuckling] Okay then, you have a nice day.
The point of all of this is that as hard as I tried, I couldn't get the person on the other end to deviate from their script in the slightest. In fact, at the very end, I even confused them slightly. They were giving irrevelant answers in attempt to get me off the phone. I wonder if it's some kind of passive-agressive thing workers do on customer service lines. The person in the above conversation could not pass a simple Turing Test. I got the exact same answer to multiple questions. Sometimes the answers didn't apply in any way to what I was asking.
Some day I'm going to start a consulting firm for customer service centers. We would train people to listen. Train managers to make sure their employees had enough lattitude to provide good service and solve problems creatively. We would hold a ceremonial burning of all three-ring binders. We would start by giving everyone on the phones a raise. Preferably a big one.

Okay, shifting gears. Here's something that's been on my mind a lot lately. How do we figure out how to lead a good life? To put it another way, how do we lead a life that leaves a positive impact on the world? I sounds like a big question, but I'm not trying to be pretentious, really. It gets to the heart of many of the lifestyle choices I've made in my life. For instance, I'm vegetarian. I'm a bad vegetarian because I eat fish. Okay, now my original motivation was somewhat political. There are issues of land use, environment, economics, etc. I won't get into it, but the basic philosophy seemed to me at the time that one could have an impact by living a certain lifestyle. Other such choices: don't drive and SUV or other large automobile, buy organic food, try not to be too rampant a consumer. Now, all that's a good start, but I don't think it's enough.
For instance, I know of at least a couple of SUV-driving, meat-eating folks who do really good work as part of their careers. One of the members of my recent canoe trip drove a Suburban. Yet, he has worked with developmentally disabled adults for over 15 years. I'm sure he's had a very real impact in a lot of lives. That's more than my vegetarian ass can say. Yet I know a lot of people that would reject him wholesale when he pulled that Suburban up in front of their house.
I see a lot of people who have the misguided notion that a certain kind of consumerism makes them a better person. They shop at co-ops, they buy only organic cotton clothes, only organic food, etc. It doesn't matter that they still buy rampantly. To them, it's okay as long as they buy the right stuff. To me it's still consumerism no matter what you consume. They don't have any idea what's going on in the world. They have not interest in understanding politics even on a local level and they don't want to. Their political action is confined to what they buy.
To me, I guess, it has to be coupled with action. It's fine to support organic farmers, co-ops and other so-called "counter-culture" accouterments. But you have to understand how to affect real political and social change. I know only a handful of people who do this. I wish I could say I did, but I really don't. The fact is that it takes a hell of a lot of energy. Energy most Americans are unwilling to expend. I could go into a Chomskian analysis of why I think this is true, but I won't. Suffice it to say that I wish I did more along these lines. Something to aim for I guess.
Okay, shifting gears again. I have a work-related story. Now, at the coffee shop where I work, the sizes are regular, large and extra large. Okay, it's not your typical small, medium, large. I can see where this might confuse some people. So, this guy comes in and orders a "regular" size drink, which he apparently took to mean "medium." (I know this sounds petty, but I'm getting to a larger point here. Hang in there.) So he get's the drink. "This is small. I ordered a regular drink." Now, I'm new still, and as I mentioned earlier, I'm somewhat timid. At this point, the store is busy and I'm a bit like the proverbial deer in the headlights. I show him the sizes. He got what he paid for.
"I hate that. Why do you guys [emphasis mine] do that? This is a small right? Everyone? This is the smallest size right? Why do you do that? You know what that is called? It's called euphemizing. It's changing the language."
Now, I wasn't doing anything. These stupid decisions where made at a much higher and presumably much more intelligent level than mine. The same level that says I can't wear green dress pants, but jeans are OK. I'm just trying to keep everyone happy, remember how to mix all their ridiculous drinks, collect my tips and go home. I don't give a shit of it's called regular, medium, or grande. What in the hell is this guy hoping to accomplish by bitching at us? Changing the language. It's like he's railing on a whole corporate culture right there in the coffee shop. Right there to it's lowest paid, least powerful members. I guess it's the price I pay for being part of it.

I've been ambivelant about Independence Day most of my adult life. As a kid, it meant fireworks. The illegal ones my neighbor had were the most exciting. It usually meant we spent the day with friends. It was a fun holiday.
As an adult I have a hard time being patriotic. I bristle at the flag-waving style of patriotism that is even more prevelant since 9/11. But the events of September 11 have forced me to reflect on what I do like about the United State of America. I've been trying to reclaim patriotism. There are things to be proud of. But how does one celebrate their country while acknowledging its faults? Its brutality?
So I tried to come up with a list of reasons why I should feel patriotic. The list was pretty short. I couldn't even think of 20. We're just too damn powerful. Too wasteful. Too short-sighted. Too greedy. Too brutal. Too hipocritical. There I go again. It really troubles me that I can't think of more positive things to say about my country. I do like it. I was going to start this blog with a fictionalized account for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as if the U.S. were Palestine. As I wrote it, I realized that I didn't have a very good knowledge of the history of the area. So I decided to do some research.
I came across urlLink Palestine, Israel and the Arab-Israeli Conflict, A Primer . I recommend that everyone read it. It dispelled a few myths about the conflict that have come up in almost every conversation I've had about it.
Myth #1 - The Conflict is essentially about religion and so may never be resolved.
Not true. It's a political conflict over urlLink land .
Myth #2 - People in that region have been fighting for thousands of years. They just hate one another. (Or some slight variation on that theme.)
Actually the source of this conflict can be traced back to Zionism, which wasn't even a movement until the late 19th century. Even then it wasn't an issue until the spread of Nazism in Europe accelerated the emigration of Jews to Israel (which was not recognized yet as a nation) while simultaneously increasing worldwide sympathy for the Zionist movement. (Even among orthodox Jews, who until then had been in strict opposition to Zionism.)
The point is, that it wasn't that long ago. It's a modern conflict.
Myth #3 - It's the Palestinians who are at fault for their terrorist tactics.
While it's true the Palestinians have used terrorist means, it's important to consider the definition of terrorism. (According to urlLink dictionary.com )
ter·ror·ism
The unlawful use or threatened use of force or violence by a person or an organized group against people or property with the intention of intimidating or coercing societies or governments, often for ideological or political reasons.
The act of terrorizing, or state of being terrorized; a mode of government by terror or intimidation.
The systematic use of violence as a means to intimidate or coerce societies or governments.
By these uncontroversial definitions of terrorism, Israel has used its share of urlLink terrorist tactics . Including:
Collective punishment Deportation of political activists Imprisonment without trial Torture
Not only that. The Israelis have done so with overwhelming force . (At least according to the U.N.)
The interesting thing is that we're the principle seller of arms to Israel.
It's strange to me that this is such a major issue in the world today, yet I don't know a single person that has any in-depth knowledge of the conflict. I certainly don't. I got all the above information from the two web sites I linked.
I don't know how to tie this all in personally for my friends who actually read this blog. I guess...I just think we should be paying more attention. I wish we all knew more, starting with me.

Truetone's Tips for the Socially Inept
I have a few friends (who actually don't read this (I don't think)) who occasionally annoy me. The thing is that they're good friends and I love them, but they need to brush up on their social skills a little so they don't inadvertantly offend people. (Like me.)
Don't give parenting advice. Especially if you haven't had young children yourself within the last five years.
If you haven't had kids recently, you've forgotten what it's like. Even if you have, parents don't really want your advice. They may ask for it, but if your advice contradicts their own ideas, they'll only be offended. Don't fall into this trap. Never give out parenting advice. You're asking for trouble.
Don't criticize someone else's driving.
Everyone thinks they drive better than everyone else. I don't care if they drive 90 mph in the left lane. They think they're a better driver than you. Driving, for whatever reason, is a very personal issue. Second only to parenting.
Never criticize someone else's family
I don't care if you're talking about their spouse, their parents, sisters, brothers or kids. They will always be defensive. At least initially. Kids are a big one. If you insult someone's kids, you're insulting them. Don't do it. People will like you better.
That's all for now. If I think of more I may post them. For now I'll let you all digest this.

Monday, July 29, 2002 - 10:15 a.m.
I'm singing Bill Monroe's "Remember the Cross" in front of the congregation of the Roaring River Baptist Church in Eagle Rock, Missouri (pronounced by the locals as "Missour a "). How did I, the consumate atheist, end up singing a country gospel song in front of a bunch of Southern Baptists? It's been a long road.
In fact, I don't even know where to start. For years now I've been a huge fan of traditional country and old-time music. A couple of years ago I brought my guitar to E's family reunion on her dad's side. I soon found out that the music I'd been studying and listening to for years was the music that they'd grown up with. So it wasn't a big surprise that they asked me to sing at the funeral. Especially since they're all in denial about the fact that E and I are atheists. I'd liked E's grandfather and despite the fact that all of her aunts and uncles were super-Christian Republicans, I like them. They're nice friendly people and we can avoid rolling eyes as long the discussion doesn't turn to politics. (Or religion.)
Plus, her aunts are tough. I know where E gets it. You don't say "no" to them.
Actually, I was honored to be asked to sing a song that I know Ray E. Skelton would have enjoyed. So I, of course, said "yes."
I don't really consider it hypocritical. I am a huge Bill Monroe fan. I love bluegrass. I'd enjoyed the small amount of time I'd spent talking with E's grandfather over the last few years. For me, it was for him. I wasn't preaching (even though the song is overtly Christian (Remember the cross on which Jesus died...He shed his blood for you and he shed his blood for me...)) I was singing an old country song in honor of a man who'd helped raise 10 kids on a Missouri dirt farm. (They all graduated from college. All of them are sucessful.) He was an activist for the democratic party in his community and only converted to Christianity at the age of 77. (He died at the age of 91.)
As I knew him, he was friendly, humorous and a good story teller.
The farm that's been part of the Skelton family for over 100 years will now be sold. Rest in peace Ray. It was nice knowing you.
